Hospitalization Record.ChiefComplaint: Fever, chills, back pain for 2 days

PresentIllness.Onset: Symptoms started abruptly 2 days ago with high fever and chills while at home.
PresentIllness.MainSymptoms: Unilateral back pain on the right side, severe and constant, not relieved by rest, accompanied by nausea and vomiting.
PresentIllness.AccompanyingSymptoms: Fever (38.8°C), urgency, frequent urination with burning sensation.
PresentIllness.DiagnosisAndTreatmentHistory: Took acetaminophen with minimal relief. No previous treatments or hospital visits for this episode.
PresentIllness.GeneralConditionChanges: Decreased appetite, normal bowel movements, increased urinary frequency, disturbed sleep due to pain.

PastHistory.ImmunizationHistory: Up to date with routine vaccinations

PersonalHistory.ExposureHistory: No known exposure to industrial toxins, dust, or radioactive substances.

MaritalAndFamilyHistory.FamilyHistory: Father had hypertension and heart disease, mother had diabetes. No family history of similar diseases or genetic tendencies.

SystematicExamination.MucousMembranes: Moist, no pallor, cyanosis, or jaundice
SystematicExamination.Chest: Clear breath sounds, normal heart sounds
SystematicExamination.Spine: Tenderness over the right lumbar area
SystematicExamination.Limbs: No edema, normal range of motion

Hospitalization Record.SpecialistExamination: Costovertebral angle tenderness on the right side.
Hospitalization Record.AuxiliaryExamination: Urinalysis shows pyuria and bacteriuria, urine culture pending. CBC shows elevated WBC count.
Hospitalization Record.DiagnosticBasis: History of fever, chills, unilateral back pain, frequent urination, and burning sensation; physical examination consistent with right-sided costovertebral angle tenderness; supportive lab findings (WBC, urinalysis).
Hospitalization Record.DifferentialDiagnosis: Ruled out acute cystitis due to the presence of systemic symptoms (fever and chills) and costovertebral angle tenderness, cholecystitis, and pancreatitis based on lack of upper abdominal pain and relevant laboratory findings; pelvic inflammatory disease ruled out due to lack of pelvic pain and discharge; ruled out febrile diseases based on urine findings and localized back pain.

Post-AdmissionCourseRecords.FirstCourseRecord: Patient admitted with acute pyelonephritis. Initiated intravenous antibiotics (Ceftriaxone). Symptomatic treatment with antipyretics and analgesics. Monitor vitals, fluid intake, and output closely.
Post-AdmissionCourseRecords.DailyCourseRecords: Day 1: Patient's fever reduced, still experiencing back pain, urine culture positive for E. coli, continue antibiotics. Day 2: Marked improvement, pain significantly reduced, continue current treatment.
Post-AdmissionCourseRecords.SeniorPhysicianRoundsRecords: Reviewed case, agrees with treatment plan, continue current management.
Post-AdmissionCourseRecords.HandoverRecords: Handover to night shift, patient's vitals stable, continue monitoring.
Post-AdmissionCourseRecords.StageSummary: Patient showing significant improvement after 2 days of treatment, continue antibiotics, reevaluate after 3 more days.

MedicalOrders.Long-termOrders: Ceftriaxone 1g IV q24h, Antipyretics PRN, Maintain strict I/O charting, Monitor vitals q4h.
MedicalOrders.TemporaryOrders: IV fluids (Normal Saline) at 75ml/hr, Acetaminophen 500mg q6h PRN for fever.

Hospitalization Record.AuxiliaryExaminationReports: CBC: WBC 15,000/uL, Urinalysis: Positive for WBCs, Positive for bacteria. Urine culture: E. coli.
Hospitalization Record.TemperatureChart: Day 1: Temp 38.8°C, Pulse 90 bpm, Resp 18/min, BP 140/85 mmHg. Day 2: Temp 37.5°C, Pulse 84 bpm, Resp 18/min, BP 135/80 mmHg.

Diseases of the Genitourinary System.Name: Acute Pyelonephritis
Diseases of the Genitourinary System.Symptoms: Fever and chills, nausea and vomiting, unilateral or bilateral back pain, frequent urination, urgency, and pain
Diseases of the Genitourinary System.Differential Diagnosis: Acute cystitis, cholecystitis, pancreatitis, pelvic inflammatory disease; in cases with high fever but no obvious urinary symptoms, differentiation should be made from various febrile diseases
